rsbNotes.title: Ex 2:11–15
rsbNotes.text: 2:11–15 Now forty years old (Acts 7:23), Moses identifies himself with God’s people (Heb. 11:24–27). His effort to deliver an Israelite from oppression proves vain when he seeks to be a judge of Israel (v. 14).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 2:15
rsbNotes.text: 2:15 Midian. Probably the name of an early tribal confederacy operating in the Arabian desert. The nomadic Midianites were descendants of Abraham and Keturah (Gen. 25:1–6; Num. 10:29–32; Judg. 6).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 2:16
rsbNotes.text: 2:16 drew water. The women did the difficult task and then were driven off.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 2:17
rsbNotes.text: 2:17 saved them. This was Moses’ third intervention in defense of the weak. Nomadic strife over water rights was common.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 2:18
rsbNotes.text: 2:18 Reuel. The name means “Friend of God.” Moses’ father-in-law was known by two names: Reuel and Jethro (3:1; 4:18). Jethro and Reuel may be variant names, or Reuel a clan name.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 2:22
rsbNotes.text: 2:22 Gershom. See text note. Moses had not forgotten his Egyptian home. Yet he will lead Israel from Egypt to the homeland of the people of God.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 2:23
rsbNotes.text: 2:23 groaned . . . cried out . . . came up. Israel’s anguished cry is balanced by a fourfold description of God’s response. God “heard . . . remembered . . . saw . . . knew” (vv. 24, 25). This summary prepares for the call of Moses and underscores the book’s theme of divine faithfulness to the covenant promises.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:1
rsbNotes.text:
3:1 wilderness. An uncultivated area but capable of sustaining grazing. According to 34:3 and Num. 10:11, the wilderness of Sinai sustained Israel’s flocks for a year. Horeb and Sinai are terms that possibly distinguish Horeb as an entire range from Mt. Sinai (19:18, 20; cf. Deut. 4:15).

mountain of God. This term describes the mountain as a sanctuary, a designation that anticipates ch. 19. Moses is now eighty years old (7:7) and has been in Midian forty years.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:2
rsbNotes.text:
3:2 angel of the Lord. This was a theophany, a visible manifestation of God (v. 4). See note Gen. 16:7.

fire. A frequent biblical symbol for God’s presence (13:21; 19:18; Gen. 3:24; 1 Kin. 18:24, 38); it particularly expresses His all-consuming holiness (Heb. 12:29).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:3
rsbNotes.text: 3:3 bush. A real bush was illumined with supernatural fire. God is transcendent, but reveals Himself in the bush to call Moses.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:5
rsbNotes.text: 3:5 holy. The spot was made sacred by God’s presence. See 19:23; 24:2. The question of how to approach the holy God is central for Exodus. It is resolved in the symbolism of the tabernacle.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:6
rsbNotes.text: 3:6 God of your father. God remembers His covenant promises to the patriarchs and identifies Himself as their God. See Gen. 26:24; 28:13; 31:42; 32:9.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:8
rsbNotes.text:
3:8 Canaanites. The inhabitants of the Syro-Palestinian coastland.

Hittites. See note Gen. 10:15.

Amorites. See note Gen. 10:16.

Perizzites. Possibly the peasantry located in central Palestine (Josh. 17:15).

Hivites. See note Gen. 10:17.

Jebusites. The original occupants of Jerusalem, later dispossessed by David (Gen. 10:16 note; 2 Sam. 5:6–9).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:10
rsbNotes.text: 3:10 Pharaoh. Probably Thutmose III (1504–1450 b.c.). See Introduction: Date and Occasion.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:11
rsbNotes.text: 3:11 Who am I. Moses felt inadequate for the task, as did Gideon (Judg. 6:15) and Jeremiah (Jer. 1:6). This is the first of his four objections (v. 14; 4:1, 10).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:12
rsbNotes.text: 3:12 sign. God’s call will be confirmed by His future action. God will be with Moses to bring him back to worship (“serve God”) on this same mountain. Having served the Egyptians, Israel will become God’s servants in covenant worship.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:13
rsbNotes.text: 3:13 What is his name. Moses anticipates a question from the people that is also his own. Already Moses seeks God’s revelation of Himself. If God’s deliverance was to be fully appreciated and assured, He who would be worshiped at this mountain must be known (33:12 and note). A personal name was not merely a form of address but a description of character and personality (Ps. 9:10; cf. 1 Sam. 25:25).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:14
rsbNotes.text: 3:14 I am who I am. The Lord is not defined or determined by any other than Himself. As the self-existent One, His promise is sure; He will reveal Himself in His saving deeds.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:15
rsbNotes.text:
3:15 The Lord. The Hebrew is Yahweh, probably derived from the Hebrew verb for “to be” (thus meaning “he is” or “he will be”). The corresponding first person is ’ehyeh, “I am.” Note the parallels: “I am has sent me” (v. 14) and “The Lord [Yahweh] . . . has sent me” (v. 15). See theological note “ ‘This Is My Name’: God’s Self-disclosure” on the next page.

remembered throughout all generations. Yahweh, the divine name particularly associated with God’s covenant relationship with Israel, was henceforth to be used in worship. English versions of the Old Testament usually render this Hebrew name as “the Lord,” following the practice of the New Testament, and of the Jews in the intertestamental period. The Jews thought the name too holy to pronounce, and when reading the text substituted ’adonay (“my Lord”). The vowel signs for ’adonay were later added to the Hebrew consonants of Yahweh as a pronunciation reminder, and this hybrid form was rendered “Jehovah” by William Tyndale’s English translation (a.d. 1530). In the New Testament, Lord (Yahweh) is applied to Jesus (Rom. 10:13, citing Joel 2:32).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:16
rsbNotes.text: 3:16 elders. Lit. “bearded ones.” These are family heads who would represent Israel. They will be assembled to hear of God’s faithfulness (4:30, 31).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:17
rsbNotes.text: 3:17 milk and honey. The usual biblical description of Canaan.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:18
rsbNotes.text: 3:18 three days’ journey. Possibly an expression for a short period of time.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:20
rsbNotes.text: 3:20 wonders. This mention of extraordinary deeds anticipates the plagues (7:14–12:30).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 3:21
rsbNotes.text: 3:21 not go empty. As He promised (Gen. 15:14), God would see that their years of bondage were recompensed.
